body.p: We consider a Work any text with an independent circulation. This does not mean it should be alone in a manuscript. A text which sometimes is added to another is also an independent work. So Genesis is a Work as Pentateuch is a Work which contains it. But Chapter 1 of Genesis is not a Work, is a part of the Work Genesis.

item.p: consider if the text you are dealing with is a WORK or a Narrative Unit Orlandi 2010, A Terminology for the identification of Coptic Literary Documents . A Work "only refers to fixed contents and a precise sequence" Bausi 2010, 34 n3
only texts with independent circulation get first level IDs, all other are textparts

if a textpart has an individual circulation in other traditions this should be said under the textpart: multuple titles can be inserted, with bibliography linking to the IDs of these titles, relations for the authors of the titles, etc.

the existing records inherited from the EAE index that do not have independent circulation in Ethiopic should be deleted, but their IDs should remain in the Google Spreadsheet, struck out with a comment specifying the new derived ID added. THE NUMERIC PART OF THESE IDS SHALL NOT BE REUSED.
if a part of a text also has an independent circulation - it gets an independent first-level ID/record
texpart divs should also be created for these texts, with a corresp link, in order to show the full content of a collection in correct order

body.p: See as example Maṣḥafa gǝnzat LIT1931Mashaf

Often the first problem to face is which records and how many to make. We accept as principle to do the maximum number of record as it is sensible and to state the minimum number of relations needed among them with a view on expanding them potentially to all what is not essential, in order to clarify their relation with each other. It might happen that different researchers have different opinions on the relation between the versions and the manuscripts and in this we will be able to host them all.

For example. If the Work A has four versions 1, 2, 3 and 4, 1 being a short version of 2 and 3 a later version of 4 while 2 and 4 differ from one another only in the order in which the content is organized, there will be 5 records, one for the abstract work, one for each version. While the abstract work will point to each of the 4 version with relations and might contain a general description of the work, each of the version will have clearly defined relations with the others and the abstract Work.

A further example: a text which is made of parts which can occur in different orders within different manuscripts. This will have 1 Work record, describing the ideal or majoritarian, or standard sequence, while each witness (Manuscript) will contain the specific order of the parts in it.

Create a new record for every different version, recensions, etc. and then express the diverse relations between the records with relation elements. This should be clearer and leave space for more differing opinions than to try to express the relations within one single record.

div.head: Title
div.p: A work file will mainly contain the edited text in the body element. It will not have instead a msDesc, although the view of the text will show manuscript which point to this work.
div.ab:
<titleStmt> <title xml:lang="gez" xml:id="t1"> <date></date> </title> <title xml:lang="gez" xml:id="t2"> <date></date> </title>
<title xml:lang="en" corresp="#t1"></title> <title xml:lang="gez" type="normalized" corresp="#t1"></title>
</titleStmt>
div.p: You can also use @type='main' to signal which one title is to be used for labels, pointers and headers. the titleStmt element will have slightly different contents. It will contain the title(s) of the work edited and the date. If there is a digital edition, a editor will be added.
Titles of the same work in another tradition will be reported following the same rule and attributing an arbitrary t+digit xml:id and the appropriate @xml:lang.
You can also use @type='short' for shortened titles like citation forms.
div.ab: <title xml:lang="gez" xml:id="t1">ወንጌል፡ ዘዮሐንስ፡</title> <title xml:lang="gez" corresp="#t1" type="normalized">Wangel za-Yoḥannǝs</title> <title xml:lang="en" corresp="#t1" type="main">Gospel of John</title> <title type="short">Jn.</title>

item.p: if a subpart of a work needs a bibliography this can be given in the div[@type='textpart']

if a subpart without independent circulation in the Ethiopic tradition needs to reference the work independently in other traditions titles will be added and referenced in the appropriate div[@type='textpart']

div.head: Edition statement, Source statement, and encoding description
div.p: These elements should be provided in the header for texts that we provide edition for. The Edition statement should specify the origin of the text. The encoding description specifies the principles used when encoding, when known (e.g. transcription, specific tag sets, etc.)
div.ab: Digital text based on .

Text prepared within the framework of the TraCES project.

The following errors in Marrassini edition have been corrected: ... ... ...

Original spelling and typography is retained.

div.head: Extent
div.ab:
Digital text based on .

 10170 words

div.head: Other Clavis ids
div.p: inside sourceDesc, there will be a section like this
div.ab: <listBibl type="clavis"> <bibl corresp="#t2coptic" type="CC"><ptr target="bm:CC"/><citedRange unit="item">123</citedRange></bibl> <bibl type="CPG"><ptr target="bm:CPG1"/><citedRange unit="item">123</citedRange></bibl> <bibl type="BHO"><ptr target="bm:BHO"/><citedRange unit="item">123</citedRange></bibl> <bibl type="CANT"><ptr target="bm:CANT1"/><citedRange unit="item">123</citedRange></bibl> <bibl type="CAVT"><ptr target="bm:CAVT2"/><citedRange unit="item">123</citedRange></bibl> <bibl type="BHL"><ptr target="bm:BHL"/><citedRange unit="item">123</citedRange></bibl> <bibl type="syriaca"><ptr target="bm:syriaca"/><citedRange unit="item">123</citedRange></bibl> <bibl type="KRZ"><ptr target="bm:KRZ"/><citedRange unit="item">123</citedRange></bibl> </listBibl>
div.p: containing ids of the work pointing eventually to the title in titleStmt.

div.head: Witnesses
div.p: We use <witness> for those manuscripts which are actually used for the edition we are going to provide in the div[@type='edition']. All catalogued manuscripts containing the work are displayed in the app anyway.
div.ab: <listWit> <witness cert="low" corresp="EMML1234"/> <witness type="external" facs="http://archivesetmanuscrits.bnf.fr/ead.html?id=FRBNFEAD000091073" corresp="BNFEAD000091073"/> <witness type="external" corresp="EMML"/> <listWit> <witness corresp="ES123"/> <witness corresp="BL8910">this manuscript was donated by <persName ref="PRS123124trhas"/>, at <placeName ref="LOC21321asa"/> and is a copy of <ref corresp="EMML2" type="mss"/> </witness> </listWit> </listWit>
div.p: listWits can be nested if needed for example to group them in families. Each witness will have to take a @corresp pointing to the manuscript @xml:id. If the manuscript is in beta mesaheft catalogue that is enough. If the manuscript is into an external catalogue, than use @type='external' as in listBibl[type='mss'] in the manuscript entity. You can use @cert to specify a degree of certainty regarding the manuscript you are listing. Please, note that each witness element can take a fully marked up description in relation to the text.

As information provided by the catalogues we are working with should not be lost, whenever a catalogue description contains references to other manuscripts containing the same work, mini ms records containing the work ID should be created for those manuscripts. This assures that all the manuscripts containing the same work can be retrieved by the app while reserving listWit in the work records mainly for the manuscripts used for the edition.

div.head: Bibliography
div.p: At the moment there are no text to be entered. However there will be. The body of the Work entity will contain a series of divs for marked up text
different listBibl will be used for separate types of entries. within listBibl[@type='editions'] each bibl will be an edition of this work. each of this editions will have used different manuscripts.
Secondary bibliographic references given in catalogues about a certain work can also be copied here, as they do not belong to the manuscript description.

div.head: Relations
div.p: Each relationship should be listed separately in a relation, even if the same relationship exists between this and more than one other entity. @name contains the name of the relation. Allowed values for relations among works and authors are those in the SAWS Ontology and those used by syriaca.org you can filter them out in oXygen typing syriaca: or saws: in the value list.
div.ab: <listRelation> <relation name="syriaca:share-a-title" active="LIT1001Homili" passive="LIT1002title"> <desc>It is always a nice idea to provide a description of this relations with a sentence or two. </desc> </relation> </listRelation>
div.p: The relationship between a work and its subject is expressed in the person record:
div.ab: <relation name="ecrm:P129i_is_subject_of" active="PRS4585Georgeo" passive="LIT1455GadlaG"/>

div.head: Authors
div.p: Please Note that we will encode AUTHORSHIP as a relation in the work record, to be more specific and explicit about the sort of authorship.
This means that the work has this author.

If a work is traditionally attributed to an author whose authorship is not currently considered to be historical, this can be expressed verbally with bibliographic references in the description of the relation, for example LIT1608hoheta:

p.seg: <relation name="saws:isAttributedToAuthor" active="LIT1608hoheta" passive="PRS3709eleni"><desc>The traditional attribution to <persName ref="PRS3709eleni"/> is considered unlikely by <bibl><ptr target="bm:Habtemichael2007Hoheta"/></bibl>.</desc></relation>

div.p: you can use many of this and also have different types for one work. If you come across records which use the author element, please correct them.

You might need to express concept which need more than one relation. For example if Person A is author of a translation B of a work C in arabic, you will need a relation of authorship between A and B (A isAuthorOf B) and the relation stating the fact that B is a translation of C (B isLooseTranslationOf C). If a digital edition of the translated work exists, please use that as a value in the relation. If no such edition exist you might point to the id of the title in the language of the original.

div.head: Versions
div.p: If you have multiple recensions/version of a text, these can be linked with a relation with @name='saws:isVersionOf' this will be used to pick up these in the text view. The same parallel content in the different versions should have the same @corresp to a NAR unit and there should always be a @resp in the div[@type='edition'] containing this text part with multiple versions with either the initials of the editor or the pointer to the xml:id of the bibl element which has a pointer to the edition.

div.head: Dates
div.p: For the date of creation of a work, use the element creation in profileDesc as in the following example
div.ab: <creation when="1555-06-23" corresp="#Pdamot">23 Sane (17 June) 1555 in <placeName ref="LOC2488Damot" xml:id="Pdamot">Damot</placeName></creation>
div.p: any other date relevant to the work elaboration or life could be added in a date element, possibly pointing to one of the placeNames in the file with a proper id as in the example below.
div.ab: <date when="1555-06-23" corresp="#Pdamot">23 Sane (17 June) 1555</date> in <placeName ref="LOC2488Damot" xml:id="Pdamot">Damot</placeName>
div.p: It is important that the id of the referred place starts with P because there are cases where corresp is already used to point to another id, e.g. a work in another tradition title. Look at this fictitious example, where I have entered a placeName with Q item id from wikidata (Ethiopia) and assigned the second corresp and the id with P
div.ab: <creation corresp="#t2arabic #Ptest" when="1238-09" > <placeName ref="Q115" xml:id="Ptest"></placeName> </creation>
div.p: this sounds like a dirty hack to get it working... and it is!

div.head: Attested placeNames
div.p: The attestations of placeNames should be marked as in the example below
div.ab: <ab> ምዕራፍ፡፱። ወእምዝ፡ ዓደወ፡ ማር፡ ገላውዴዎስ፡ ማዕዶተ፡ ክልኤቱ፡ አፍላግ፡ መንገለ፡ ምድረ፡ <placeName ref="LOC5597Sawa" notBefore="1540" notAfter="1559">ሼዋ፡</placeName> እመንገለ፡ምድረ፡ <placeName ref="LOC5932Tegray" notBefore="1540" notAfter="1559">ትግራይ፡</placeName> ከመ፡ ይርአይ፡ መርዔቶ፡ bእለ፡ ህየ፡ በጽድቅ፡ ወይዋሄ፡ cሕዝቦ፡ በርትዕ። ወበጽሐ፡</ab>
div.p: to choose which id to use consider the following:

item.p: if it is a place of interest for ethiopian studies or attested in ethiopia, then use one of our internal ids or create a new record if none is yet available
if it is an ancient place not of our interest and not relevant for pleiades, check in wikidata and enter the item id (starting with Q)

div.p: you can also add a @resp with the id of one of our person records or editors and a @source with a list of bm:tags from the Zotero Ethiostudies group library.

div.head: Short Summary of Contents
div.p: To provide a short summary of contents use the element abstract in as in this example from Confessio Claudii
div.ab: A theological treatise believed to be a responce of king Galāwdewos to the Jesuit missionaries headed by Oviedo.
div.p: The abstract can also mention the total number of words, which might be then marked up with a measure[@type='words'] within the abstract.
Summaries given in catalogues can be copied here and edited.

div.head: Keywords
div.p: These keywords are used for the whole record. You can use one or more of the values provided for @key.
div.ab: <textClass> <keywords> <term key=“Liturgy”/> </keywords> </textClass>

div.head: divs edition and textparts
div.ab: ዝውእቱ ፡ አስማቲሆሙ ፡ ለደቂቀ ፡ እስራኤል ፡ እለ ፡ ቦኡ ፡ ብሔረ ፡ ግብጽ ፡ ምስለ ፡ ያዕቆብ ፡ አቡሆሙ ፡ [ለ]ለአሐዱ ፡ አሐዱ ፡ በበ ፡ አዕጻዲሆሙ ፡ ቦኡ ። ሮቤል ፡ ወስምዖን ፡ ወሌዊ ፡ ወይሁዳ ። ወይ[ሳኮ]ር ፡ ወዛቡሎን ፡ ወብንያም ።
div.p: Please be careful in always stating the sources for the description of a work, especially for the division of the work into textparts and other structural decisions. Ideally this source should be an edition, but if none exists, state if the description follows for example the EAe or a manuscript.
div.ab: <div type="edition"> <note>This division into textparts follows <ref type="mss" corresp="FSUrueppII2"/>.</note> <div type="textpart" subtype="book" n="1" xml:id="Kefl1" xml:lang="gez">
div.p: Note that after each word there should be a separator or punctuation without space.
If the text contains verses we will use l as in the example above. Also lb can be used to mark linebreaks, for example in Inscriptions. Be carefull: ab should be only in the lowest level div nesting!
to identify a div you can use a label
or a corresp pointing to another work

div.head: Languages
div.p: within langUsage all languages used in the file should be defined. It is not a problem if one of these statements is not relevant to the current record, but if another language is used, it should be defined.
div.ab: <langUsage> <language ident="en">English</language> <language ident="it">Italian</language> <language ident="gez">Gəˁəz</language> </langUsage>
div.p: If you add somewhere e.g. <title xml:lang="am"/>, there should be a language element in langUsage like the following

<language ident="am">Amharic</language> the values of @ident here are restricted, so you should not be able to add e.g. amh as value for @ident and consequently use it in the file as value of @xml:lang.

div.head: Narrative Units
div.p: The model file for a Narrative Unit is much simpler. Just assign a title to your file and add in the body a short description. You can mark up content as in any other entity. Recommended but not compulsory are a bibliography and a listBibl[@type='relations'].

Narrative units can also be created for text portions (paragraphs, chapters, miracles, etc.) which are extant as different versions in multiple recensions of the same work or even in different works. Creating these narrative units allows displaying in the app all the existing interrelated versions of that text. See, e.g., NAR0013pelican, i.e., the chapter on the pelican in the Physiologus. Once a single narrative unit ID is provided as div[@corresp] in correspondence of the text edition in the Work records of the different recensions (e.g., <div type="textpart" subtype="chapter" xml:id="ch4" n="4" corresp="NAR0013pelican">), all the existing versions of that narrative unit will be visualized in the app by clicking the Versions button in the Text page of the work record.
